landingPages.title: Welcome
landingPages.question: Socket cannot be held responsible for any damages or injuries.

landingPages.title: Welcome
landingPages.question: Carefully read and follow all instructions. Many mechanical problems are solved with simple solutions.

pages.title: Lets Begin!
pages.question: Make sure the engine switch and choke are in the ON position. Turn the key or use the pull cord. Does the engine start?

pages.title: Not starting
pages.question: OK. Is it an electric start or a pull cord?

pages.title: Not starting
pages.question: Ok, go ahead and give it another try. Does the engine turn over?

pages.title: Not starting
pages.question: Please make sure that all engine safeties are engaged.'Pressing the brakes, mower is off, transmission is in neutral, etc.' Does it start now?

pages.title: Battery
pages.question: OK, let's take a quick look at the battery. You will need a voltmeter for the next few steps.

pages.title: Battery
pages.question: Touch the voltmeter prods to the appropriate battery terminals. Is it reading 12V?

pages.title: Battery
pages.question: Charge or replace battery.

pages.title: Ignition Electrical
pages.question: Ok, now we need to locate the starter. 'Be careful around the starter terminals as the power one is always live.'

pages.title: Ignition Electrical
pages.question: You will need a voltmeter. Place the positive prod on the starter terminal. Ground the negative prod on solid steel or the battery's negative terminal.

pages.title: Ignition Electrical
pages.question: Is is reading 12V or higher?

pages.title: Ignition Electrical
pages.question: The cable from the starter to battery is cut, frayed, or disconnected.

pages.title: Ignition Electrical
pages.question: OK, let us get into some electrical. A test light might help. Ground the test light onto the steel frame. Press the test light onto the starter solenoid terminal 'smaller wires'.

pages.title: Ignition Electrical
pages.question: Again, attempt to start the engine. Does the light illuminate when the key is turned?

pages.title: Ignition Electrical
pages.question: Ok, the problem is most likely a loose connection, or a broken or cut wire somewhere between the battery and the starter.

pages.title: Ignition Electrical
pages.question: Hmmm, you might need a new starter or solenoid. Did you know you can bench test a starter?!

pages.title: Engine Troubleshooting
pages.question: We will be putting the battery to work so make sure you keep it charged through the troubleshooting process.

pages.title: Engine Troubleshooting
pages.question: Here we go! During our trouble shooting stage, please keep hands clear of moving parts, use common sense, and be safe.

pages.title: Engine Troubleshooting
pages.question: OK! Any engine needs, fuel, spark, compression, timing. Its that simple.

pages.title: Engine Troubleshooting
pages.question: Let us start with spark as its the quickest to verify.

pages.title: Engine Troubleshooting
pages.question: Let us go ahead and remove the spark plug boots. Now remove the plugs from the cylinder. Re-attach spark plugs to the boots. Ground the spark plug ends to the engine or steel frame.

pages.title: Engine Troubleshooting
pages.question: WARNING! Wedge the spark plugs so that you don’t need to hold them in place. You could shock yourself. Or you can wear rubber gloves.

pages.title: Engine Troubleshooting
pages.question: Go ahead and turn the key. As the engine rotates, look for constant spark at the spark plug end. A strong blue spark is a good spark. A weak yellow spark is worse and may lead to misfires.

pages.title: Ignition Electrical
pages.question: Is the spark blue and constant?

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: Is there any spark?

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: Do you have a points system?

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: On both spark plugs?

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: Alright, there is intermittent or a weak spark on both spark plugs. Do you have a points system?

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: Gotcha. I think we should open the points box.

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: A good telltale sign of worn out points is blue arcing in the points box.

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: As you crank over the engine, can you see any signs of arcing in the points box?

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: If you see any arcing, that is most likely the problem. Try adjusting the points gap first. If that did not fix it, remove and replace the condenser and points system.

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: Ok, I'm leaning towards a bad spark plug wire.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Swap the spark plug wires. Does the other spark plug work now?

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: Remove and replace spark plug wires.

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: Ok. You're most likely looking at a bad coil.

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: You have a defective spark plug.

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: Ok, you're probably looking at a weak or bad coil.

pages.title: Incomplete
pages.question: Were sorry, this app isn't finished.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Good enough, please re-install the spark plug and attach the boots. Let's move on to Fuel.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Fuel is the most common cause of small engine failure. Let's begin!

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Do you have gas? Please, visually check. We're not kidding. This happens all the time. Add some. Did that fix it?

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Ok, is the fuel petcock valve closed?

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Hmmm, let's go in deeper. WARNING! Fuel is flammable. Don't smoke nearby during these steps. Keep a glass fuel jar handy as well as a few rags.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Shut off fuel petcock valve. Follow the fuel line from the gas tank to the engine carburetor. Unplug the fuel line at the carburetor end. If you have a fuel pump, disconnect it there.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Put the end of the fuel line in a glass jar and make sure it is lower than the gas tank; this test is relies on gravity.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Open up the petcock fuel valve. As long as the jar is lower than the gas tank, there should be a good fuel flow. You can now close the petcock fuel valve. Was there good fuel flow?

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Good news, this is most likely and easy fix. Reasons you don’t have good fuel flow might be; broken gas cap vent, broken petcock valve, clogged fuel line, clogged fuel filter, and/or bottom of your gas tank is clogged.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Ok, do you have a fuel pump?

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Fuel pumps work one of three ways. Electrical pumps work off the battery.  Mechanical and vacuum pump work off the engines rotation. Which one do you have?

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Mechanical and vacuum pumps. Disconnect the fuel pump at the carb. Put the fuel line in a glass jar. Turn the key to the START position to get the engine turning and observe that the is fuel spurting in the jar.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Electrical fuel pump. Disconnect the fuel line at the carb. Put the fuel line in a glass jar. Turn the key to the ON position, you should hear the fuel pump priming and see fuel flow.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Is there good fuel flow?

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Replace or rebuild the fuel pump.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Reconnect the fuel lines. On to the carburator!

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: A carburetor can seem intimidating but its a fairly simple system. Just remember to keep everything clean.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Find the carburetor, find the carburetor bowl. With a rag in hand, unscrew the drain screw or plug on the bowl. There won’t be much fuel, depending on engine size, 1 to 2 ounces.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Is there fuel dripping out?

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Hmmm, I'm going to guess that the carburetor's float needle is stuck.  You should clean the carb and replace all gaskets with new ones.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Ok, let's quickly perform a intake vacuum test. Did you know engines use air vacuums for many things? One of the vacuum systems is responsible for fuel delivery in the cylinders.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Let's give this a try. Remove the air filter along with the air box.  With the palm of your hand, fully block the intake port. Turn the key to the START position. While the engine is turning, listen carefully.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Do you hear a high pitch whistle?

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: You have an intake vacuum leak. This must be located and fixed before further diagnostics, as it causes undesirable symptoms.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Ok, last fuel related test. With all fuel lines connected, turn the key to the START position for 5 sec. Now quickly remove the spark plugs.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Touch and smell the spark plug. Is the spark plug end wet and does it smell like fuel?

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: If you have good fuel flow from the gas tank to the carb and don’t have an intake leak, than we must assume the carb is the culprit. The jets might be clogged and/or the gasket might be ripped.

pages.title: Engine troubleshooting
pages.question: Ok, good enough. We have to assume fuel system works. On to compression!

pages.title: Testing Compression
pages.question: We will need a compression gauge for this next test. Disconnect and remove the spark plugs.

pages.title: Testing Compression
pages.question: Screw the gauge fitting into the cylinder head. Be sure to use the correct fitting as it could damage piston head. If unsure, you can slowly turn the engine by hand using the flywheel to ensure piston full travel.

pages.title: Testing Compression
pages.question: Turn the key to the START position for 3 seconds. Read the gauge and take note. Repeat process on the other cylinder.

pages.title: Testing Compression
pages.question: Compare readings to your engine specs. As a general rule of thumb, a cylinder with compression rating between 90 and 110 PSI will work. Are the cylinder pressures in range?

pages.title: Testing Compression
pages.question: Aha! Reasons for low compression. Blown head gasket, stuck or sticking valves, scored cylinder, and/or damaged piston rings.

pages.title: Engine Troubleshooting
pages.question: Compression checks out! Last but not least... timing.

pages.title: Testing Timing
pages.question: We will need a timing light for this test. Small engines have timing marks on the flywheel. These can be tricky to find, but they are there.

pages.title: Testing Timing
pages.question: Once located, connect the timing light. One lead to the positive terminal of the battery. The other between the spark plug and the boot. Turn the key to the START position.

pages.title: Testing Timing
pages.question: Point the light to the timing mark. As the light flashes along with engine rotation, the timing marks should be aligned. Are the marks aligned?

pages.title: Engine Troubleshooting
pages.question: Timing is correct. The engine should start. If not we recommend restarting this trouble shooting app.

pages.title: Testing Timing
pages.question: Ah! Reasons the engine timing could be off are timing chain failure or wear, or the ignition time needs to be retarded or advanced.

pages.title: Engine Tune Up
pages.question: Does the engine run for more then 20 seconds with the choke on?

pages.title: Engine Tune Up
pages.question: Slowly move the choke to the off position. Is the engine still running?

pages.title: Testing Timing
pages.question: Ok, This is most likely a fuel delivery problem. More specifically a clogged idle jet. Remove the carb and clean, rebuild, or replace it.

pages.title: Engine Tuning
pages.question: If cleaning, take specific care in cleaning the jets. Soak them in cleaning solution for 12 hours, then carefully run a wire through the jets, and finally clean them out with compressed air.

pages.title: Engine Tune Up
pages.question: Alright, slowly moving up the throttle now. Is it still running?

pages.title: Testing Timing
pages.question: Hmmm, it is most likely a fuel delivery problem. More specifically a clogged main jet. Remove the carb and clean, rebuild, or replace it.

pages.title: Engine Tune Up
pages.question: If cleaning, take specific care in cleaning the jets. Soak them in cleaning solution for 12 hours, then carefully run a wire through the jets, and finally clean out with compressed air. Did that fix it?

pages.title: Testing Timing
pages.question: Lets give this a try. Wear rubber gloves. While the engine is running at idle, pull one of the spark plug boots off. The engine should still run on one cylinder.

pages.title: Engine Tune Up
pages.question: Re-install the spark plug boot and perform the task again on the opposite cylinder. Did the engine keep running?

pages.title: Engine Tuning
pages.question: We're not sure what is wrong with your engine. Please check back with us at a later time as we are continuously upgrading the app.

pages.title: Engine Tuning
pages.question: If the engine died when you pulled off a spark plug boot, then the opposite spark plug is the culprit. Reasons why can be; a bad spark plug, a bad spark plug wire and/or a bad coil.

pages.title: Engine Tune Up
pages.question: Is the engine RPM surging up and down?

pages.title: Testing Timing
pages.question: An engine that is surging up and down is usually suffering from a bad carburator adjustment and/or improperly gaped spark plugs. There are two screws that help with carburetor adjustment. An idle screw and a mixture screw.

pages.title: Engine Tuning
pages.question: Together they can help with the surging RPM. Also ensure the spark plugs are well gaped by using a filler gauge.

pages.title: Engine Tuning
pages.question: We're not sure what's wrong with your engine. Please check with us at a later time as we are always upgrading this app.

pages.title: OK. Is it electrical start or pull cord?
pages.question: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Maecenas id dolor odio. Pellentesque habitant morbi tristique senectus et netus et malesuada fames ac turpis egestas.

pages.title: Engine Tuning
pages.question: Ok, This is most likely a fuel delivery problem.  More specificaly a stuck needle or a badly adjusted float.

pages.title: Finished!
pages.question: Thank you for using Socket.  Hope we helped you with your engine diagnostics.

pages.title: Oops!
pages.question: We don't have a page here yet - click 'Back' to try again.
